evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was observed and documented in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 during the hist_baseline_t0_prelim phase.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew is resistant to defeaters as alternative causes like equipment failure or external interference were ruled out in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident analysis.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The root cause of communication/coordination breakdown among crew fits key features such as miscommunication, lack of clear protocols, and failure to follow standard operating procedures in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was observed and documented in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 during the hist_baseline_t0_prelim phase.

assumptions: The observed interactions and incident outcome imply communication/coordination breakdown
The evidence sufficiently captures crew communication during the incident
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination without breakdown
If procedural deviation rather than communication failure was the primary cause

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H4 documents communication and coordination among crew and tug operators, showing interaction and a breakdown leading to the incident, supporting the claim of communication/coordination breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in distinguishing communication breakdown from procedural deviation

node.statement: The root cause of communication/coordination breakdown among crew fits key features such as miscommunication, lack of clear protocols, and failure to follow standard operating procedures in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident.

assumptions: Assuming that the failure to stop at the TRP and continued movement beyond it reflects communication/coordination breakdown rather than solely procedural deviation or environmental factors.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear protocols were followed and communication was effective, or if the cause was primarily environmental or marking deficiencies rather than crew coordination.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H4 shows communication among crew and tug operators, decisions to stop and resume pushback, and failure to stop at the TRP, indicating miscommunication and procedural failures consistent with communication/coordination breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Ambiguity in whether procedural deviations or environmental factors were primary cause; limited detail on protocols and communication clarity.

node.statement: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew is resistant to defeaters as alternative causes like equipment failure or external interference were ruled out in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident analysis.

defeaters: Explicit evidence ruling out equipment failure or external interference as causes would change my mind.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H1-H4) describes crew communication and pushback events but does not explicitly rule out alternative causes like equipment failure or external interference, so defeater resistance is not supported.
